reviews.review:
Portal is only about 4 hours long, but since it seems like everyone I know has also got about 4 hours on the dot logged into this game by the time they finish it, I think it's safe to say those 4 hours are immaculately paced. That optimal pacing is good since those 4 hours will be spent doing basically nothing but puzzles. If that pacing didn't already clue you in, those puzzles are also very enjoyable to complete. Each puzzle was enjoyable to solve, required me to think outside the box, and utilized the game mechanics in clever ways. The best part is that some of the puzzles have different ways of solving them, providing more replay value and making each solution feel like it was your own. Multiple solutions doesn't mean they're easy though- in fact the last few puzzles left me scratching my head for quite a while. Luckily this head scratching never gets dull as GLaDOS, your test chamber companion, will pipe up with witty banter from time to time reminding you that you're a rat in the aperture science labyrinth, trying to solve puzzles and escape, while not letting you forget how much of a laughably ancillary priority you are in her eyes. The commentary never ceases to be full of life and character and the sinister underlying themes and hilarious personifications of inanimate objects contrast to provide a facility that feels clean and pristine, but with a diabolical scheme behind the scenes. Overall, it's a complete package that manages to thoroughly impress, which is a testament to the game's quality given the relatively short runtime. A classic that I'd recommend to:
- Anyone looking to play well-received games to culture themselves or looking to step outside their comfort zone
- Anyone interested in puzzlers
- Anyone who enjoys lore or interesting themes and characterization
No matter what, you won't be disappointed. It's an excellent game.
Absolutely fantastic game. You cannot disagree.

Portal est un jeu de r√©flexion √† la premi√®re personne o√π vous incarnez Chell, une femme servant de sujet √† une exp√©rience scientifique, faisant office de cobaye humain dont les actions sont guid√©es par une voix synth√©tique.
Au travers d'une suite de salles dont la configuration change au fil de son parcours, elle devra se frayer un chemin en jouant sur les lois de la physique en empruntant des portails dimensionnels.
Si le jeu peut sembler aust√®re au premier abord, il sait se montrer didactique et propose une difficult√© progressive. Les m√©caniques de jeu sont habilement expliqu√©es petit √† petit, de mani√®re √† ce que le joueur assimile les bases qui lui permettront de venir √† bout des salles plus complexes.
Mais le jeu offre bien plus en lui apportant une dimension suppl√©mentaire inattendue et particuli√®rement rafra√Æchissante.
Portal pose les bases d'un concept qui trouvera litt√©ralement son apog√©e dans sa suite directe, Portal 2, il a d'autre part une dur√©e de vie courte, mais il serait dommage de l'occulter dans la mesure o√π c'est par lui qui tout a commenc√©.

I was lucky enough to go in blind as a gaming noob with a bad computer and loved every moment. The mechanics are engaging, voice acting is flawless, environmental story telling is fascinating and the sense of isolation is captivating. I got stuck on some of the puzzles but after a a few days or pondering managed to work it out, which was a great feeling every time. The Portal series hold up to time and holds a special place in my heart.

After 100% completing the game I kind of feel obligated to do this: If you have a computer with steam on it and you do not own portal, something is wrong. It really is a masterpiece that I think everyone should get to experience. The game along with portal 2 (also a masterpiece) go on big sales very often, so you really don't have a reason not to own it. The game is very short too, i managed to 100% it in only 10 hours. Because of how short it is I'd say almost anyone has time to complete it. Overall the game is great and it really is a must play.
